posts.com:
While most small arms don't seem to hurt Terminators, and according to Kyle he wouldn't be able to destroy one "with these weapons", Terminators can't just stand and tank hits, and can get knocked down with enough force.

In the police station shootout, the Terminator only takes a few hits from AR-15s, and gets more "tactical" once they're broken out. IE he doesn't just stand still and take shots repeatedly.

Presumably armor-piercing ammunition or especially powerful small arms could damage a Terminator. How many soldiers would it take, with conventional weapons, to destroy one?

posts.com:
>>177867184
The narrative requires it to be an unstoppable killing machine so to that purpose, in the context of a movie, there's no number of guys that could stand between it and a 1v1 showdown with its target.

Realistically, depending on their equipment, training, and knowledge of the enemy, and on the terrain, a squad-size element could do it or certainly a platoon. An M16/M4 shoots little 5.56mm rounds that won't punch through the heavy steel parts, but they will pierce the flesh and become little pieces of metal that will get stuck in the moving parts of the T-800. The eyes are also vulnerable, a bunch of shots to the head and some will pierce the glass eyes it uses to see and enter the electronic components inside the head. Shrapnel-producing grenades will absolutely fuck this thing up for the same reason, a bunch of little chunks of metal flying everywhere will get caught inside all the complex moving parts and render it immobile, and the shockwave of explosions and the impact of projectiles will still damage the comparatively delicate electronics inside just by shaking it around enough. An anti-tank recoilless rifle would destroy a T-800 and a Barrett M82 or other anti-materiel rifle will probably do so as well.

The Terminator movies also operate on different timeline, T1 takes place on the third timeline (if I remember correctly).

there was a thing in the book that tied it all together (the movie is better).
When the apes touch the monolith one of the apes gets the idea to stick a lepard head onto a spear and run at the other tribe of apes with it. It then is said, "He didn't quite know what to do with his new found power, but he was sure he could think of something"
Then at the end of the book when star child approaches earth. All of the nations shoot their nuclear missles at him. He denates them with his mind and then he looks at earth and it is said, "He didn't quite know what to do with his new power, but he was sure he could think of something." It was cute.
The main appeal of the movies and the book is observing the space fetishism that was absolutely infested in pop culture since the moon landing. Humanity had a hope that space would reap some great advancement. Star Trek, 2001, star wars, etc. All had this great incredible hope in space travel. It has died significantly in recent years. And we can look back at the infatuation with space of the 60s and 70s as a quaint nativity. We now are slowly realizing that Science itself is not the sole answer to human advancement. It has extreme limits- such as it having absolutly no say in ethics, which as Plato said was the main purpose in human civilization. The good life, as it were. Humanity, since the scientific revolution has neglected his other disciplines. Like a child that only does his math homework, sure he is good at geometry, but he sucks at biology now lol. Science is good at revealing nature, but it has a stern limit.
Anyway, like the hope of space travel 2001 is stupid and a lie.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>177865088

As I've aged, I have uniroincally come to appreciate The Dawn of Man as an excellent part of the film, equal to the rest. It is not a chore that must be "got through" before one gets to the cool space stuff, which was generally how I thought of it as a kid. It can be watched and enjoyed as a short film in its own right, divorced from the rest of the picture.

It is the simplest story that can possibly be conceived, and it is beautifully shot. There is a simple problem, and there is a conflict with others. If the problem is not solved, the group will surely die. God intervenes. Suddenly, and with great drama, they understand how they can solve their problem. They confront the others, defeat them in battle, and celebrate. The End, if you like, and all without a single word.

The monolith (God, higher intelligence, alien, Van Neumann probe etc) stimulates early man to evolve.
2001, moon Men find another monolith sending a signal to pluto.
Humans investigate accompanied by Hal. HAL will not deviate the mission and murders crew members.
Boman, after deactivating HAL, learns of the "alien artifact" found on the moon. He investigates the location of the 3rd monolith which opens a Stargate.
Boman travels to the big bang and witnesses the creation of time and space, witnesses his own life and then, again stimulated mentally by the monolith, he transcends (the way the apes did) and is reborn as an advanced "Star Child", returning to Earth.

No. You don't. There are good aspects about it, but the fucking arsty-fartsy shit this guy is talking about is exactly what it looks like and fucks up an otherwise enjoyable experience.

Watch the sequel 2010 if you want something that makes some kind of coherent sense, and see what 2001 could have been if they'd just given you something more to work with.

PROTIP: Anyone could do a 'aliens so advanced nothing they do seems to make any sense' movie, just insert random bullshit, but that's not a very interesting or coherent story.

The perfect example of how gay that shit can get is Interstellar where they obviously can't show extra dimensions, so they instead come up with random retarded shit like he's in his daughter's closet moving sand of the floor or some shit. Totally fucking retarded. Just because the black hole depiction and time dilation are real and depicted in a semi-accurate way, doesn't mean you get to go full-retard and gayness with the rest of the shit.

Likewise with 2001, did you know it takes a long time to get anywhere in SPAAAAAAAAAAACE and there's no sound? Here that shit on film portrayed relatively accurately. Are we having fun yet?

Yeah, and realistically Luke Skywalker has to take a shit every now and then on Dagobah, doesn't mean I want/need to see him actually doing it. The art of a story is carefully selecting the most interesting slice out of an entire universe that actually has some kind of meaning or value. That's why the Prequels and Sequels sucked so much. They weren't. They were just mostly shit nobody cared about that happened to be going on in that universe while there was a war going on:

posts.com:
Me? I'd send Warwick Davis to a concentration camp. As he steps off the ramp at the train station, still shivering from the long ride in the cold (but not very cramped, for Warwick is my only prisoner) cattle cart, he will lay eyes on me, dressed in a fine uniform covered by a doctor's overcoat.
I'll order Warwick to strip down, reminding him of the fates of the seven dwarfs of Auschwitz if he doesnt't comply.
"But I made that story up," he'll bawl, "you can't honestly believe that all this happened to little people, but the family of gnomish dwarfs managed to survive none the worse for wear? It's not real!"
I smile diabolically at his use of the d-word, but deep inside I am disappointed in him for starting to break already. Nonetheless I lean in and tell him: "We can make it real."
With a snap of my fingers I command my loyal and cruel Capo Peter Dinklage to take Warwick away. The diabolical dwarf, already intimidated by his surroundings and the size of his gigantic guard is helped on his way by a series of whacks delivered to the back of his stubby legs with a cudgel I've made sure to equip my friend and confidante with.
Later that day, Peter and I will have an ecxellent dinner at a table outside the window of Warwick's barracks. There is no glass in the frame, but however much he tries, there is no escape for Warwick, as the window is at least a good 40 centimetres from the ground. As the detestable creature is forced to fight off mites for his scraps of bread crust, he is forced to smell the aroma of our dinner wafting past him and listen to our laughter.
"Another glass of wine, Peter, oldest of my friends?" I will ask and with a hearty laugh Peter accepts, handing me another plate of the finest Roast beef.
But this will be the last instance of merrymaking in the camp for a short while, for while Warwick shivers in his little shoebox at night, hoping that no hungry rodent will find him, Peter and I are hard at working preparing our guest's stay.

Early in the morning, Warwick will be awoken by Peter picking up his bed and turning it over, making sure that Warwick doesn't disappear between the floorboards. Then, the lecherous Leprechaun will be led off the campgrounds to perform backbreaking work for our amusement. We will set Warwick up to crush Rocks, pebbles to any normal sized person, and cut down trees that are closer to stalks of grass than anything else.
Once Warwick can't go on anymore, his deformed little body wrecked by exhaustion and spasms of pain, Peter will offer to take him to the doctor. Warwick, eager as always to stretch out his life for as long as he can, accepts.
But once he arrives at the camp doctor's office, his relief turns to horror as he recognizes me.
"Ah, Mr Davis," I laugh, the perfect picture of jovial friendliness, "what appears to be the problem?"
"No," Warwick wheezes, "not you. Let me go, I feel much better already. I swear!"
Undaunted, I roll my chair closer to my vertically challenged patient
"A little short of breath, are we?" I expertly deduce, "in fact, a little short overall. But let's cut this short, Mr Davis. I am sure that we can help you here."
In his office, Peter nods along with the rythm of the screams echoing through the camp as I get to work.
Racks, experimental gene therapy, Chinese leg lengthening surgery: No method I don't try in my quest to uplift the vile imp, but alas, there is no success to be had against the genetic nightmare of Warwick's DNA.
Finally, I call Peter to bring Mr Davis back to his accomodation.
"But don't worry, one day we will find a way to help you. However long it takes." I assure my patient as he is carried away in the palm of my diligent assistant's hand.
That will be the midge's new routine: Day after day of backbreaking labor interspersed with medical experimentation. I guess we would fumigate his barracks every now and then to make sure that no curious flea carries away our prize.

>>177876502
>Give me speicific examples, I don't get it.
This is my personal opinion. Others here might say Dreyer is filmed theater whereas German isn't. I'd say he is. If you were there in person watching Hard To Be A God instead of watching it through a camera, it would essentially be a theater play. So it's filmed theater, which is superior to stage theater.
On the other hand, most experimental cinema is closer to "filmed photography/visual art". If you were there in person, you couldn't really think of it as theater. You'd just be looking at the world.
Neither is better or worse, those are just the two types of film.

Well, since we're sharing these kinds of stories. When I was 8 there was this girl, also 8 who lived in an apartment across from mine. There was a swimming pool in the middle of the apartments. She was pale with dark hair, either white or half white half hispanic as her mom was a redhead. One day after school we saw her sitting outside her apartment crying, she'd been locked out for some reason. My mom felt bad, so we took her with us to get some pizza so she wouldn't be alone for a couple hours. When we got back, she asked if I would go out with her, but I pretended I didn't know what she meant because I found her kind of off-putting. It feels weird to say in retrospect but I kind of saw her as a slut and suspected she must be doing stuff with all the boys in the neighborhood, though they kinda didn't like her either. I thought this because she was always taking off her shirt to show off her nipples. It was this weird pull for me of "You shouldn't be doing that." against "I kinda wanna look though." I remember thinking even then someone's probably molesting her, even if I didn't fully understand the implications of that. She'd always claim her mother was a prostitute and that she brought a lot of guys home and they watched a lot of dirty movies. She'd always want me to watch her strip and invite me to watch her take a shower. One time she wanted to play a game where we each closed our eyes and the other could do whatever they wanted to them. Favorite:

Stalker (1979)
The Ninth Configuration (1980)
Alien (1979)
Apocalypse Now Redux
Sunshine/The Thin Red Line


Least Favorite:

Normally I hate a lot of movies but for me to truly hate something, I have to be motivated enough to despise it with every fiber of my being. Anything like capeshit or midwit cinema is too easy to do so I have to choose carefully among the films I hate the most:

For me it's:

>Schnidler's List

I fucking hate Spielberg and his direction toward forcibly pandering us to sympathize with the Holocaust, in addition to the melodramatic music and self-advocating tone of the film.

>Lawrence of Arabia

An inaccurate portrayal of a self-contradictory behemoth who vehemently exploited the hospitality of the Arabs to his own advantage. While the movie would go out of its way to lie to the viewer about his kindness and disposition toward them, he was, in many ways more than one, a smug asshole with no sense of shame or self-regard.

>The Godfather

This is less "hate" and "care" and more about the fact that it puts me to sleep every time I watch it. The movie is so goddamn boring and slow that I can BARELY tell what's going on. While there are some good performances to be had by people like Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, Robert Duvall (who is also in Apocalypse Now), these names can't carry the plot if I don't know or can't tell what's going on.

>Dead Poets Society

Gaslights the audience into thinking that suicide is a viable solution towards not achieving your dreams. Fuck this movie. Reminds me of my worst days in private HS that I still am haunted by.

>Any film by Quentin Tarantino that isn't Reservoir Dogs or Jackie Brown

Honestly, fuck the guy. He's basically the Kanye West of films in that he emulates/imitates/duplicates/copies what other films did and uses them to create a pastiche more than a film.

>>177787857

Yes, it has a lot of elements, neo-noir, erotic, horror, but can't really be pinned down to any one. It's a real melting pot kind of film, and a lot of the choices are disorienting, deliberately or not. Like, at one point, with the language and mentally based communication issues, I wondered if the daughter really was the woman he was looking for, the 'mother' was really the daughter who killed the father and then took his place as the abuser, and the guy hung around to try and break the girl's conditioning and rescue her. It wasn't at all. Or if his shoulder wound meant that he was in a loop, or events were out of sequence, imagination, etc. Not those, either! But I like that the film has so much confusion, you're kind of going mad with it, trying to make sense with things that are in front of you but not quite.

Okay fellas, I just finished Tsui Hark's THE BUTTERFLY MURDERS (1979)

Well I was fucking tricked because this was not particularly /hor/ related, save for several jarring scenes involving the titular butterfly murders, which are played as horrible and frightening, with their screeching cacophony music. But sadly that's it, not even the black armoured stranger is very spooky, he's more of a mysterious figure than menacing.

But, as is typical of Hark flicks, it's dynamic with fun camerawork and characters that keeps the fairly short movie feeling fresh. Also has a bunch of cute girls to keep looking at, especially Green Shadow. The plot, however, about killer butterflies, martial arts espionage, and secret weapons production, completely lost me at a point, but I suspect that was partly the poor out of synch subs as much as it was a messy story. Sadly a rare film, too, the only working public torrent is in 480p.

The score was great, and so was the ending, but it's all too bloated to enjoy. There was a lot of filler with random psychic tavern owner, which was very melodramatic but didn't pay off with much.

I'd avoid this one, lads.

>>177841769

So what?

Alien, the Thing and The Exorcist are massively influential, available, and discussed horror films, so many people will encounter them first or early in their horror viewing lives, are often on TV, etc. So, either nostalgia, or beyond nostalgia looking at horror as a whole, those three will often be in best of favourite lists, and deservedly so.

Similar with Blair Witch, especially for people at the time of release.

Texas Chainsaw is a solid pick for slashers, and any one who likes the subgenre will probably pick on of the big three. It would be my pick, too, for its strangeness and beauty, and constant atmosphere.

28 Days is prime example of rage-zombies and fast paced survival horror, also nostalgia pick for many.

Signalman and Mungo have similar themes, anon seems to have an unfortunate preference for FF. Noroi fits into that.

So you have some of the best and strongest examples of horror, with a bias towards FF, with some of the best examples in (mostly aweful) subgenre.

What's your list?

>Wayne Williams

Williams first became a suspect in the Atlanta murders on the morning of May 22, 1981, when a police surveillance team, watching the James Jackson Parkway bridge spanning the Chattahoochee River (a site where several victims' bodies had been discovered), heard a "big loud splash", suggesting that something had been thrown from the bridge into the river below.[4][5] The first automobile to exit the bridge after the splash, at roughly 2:50 a.m., belonged to Williams. When stopped and questioned, he told police that he was on his way to check on an address in a neighboring town ahead of an audition the following morning with a young singer named Cheryl Johnson. However, both the phone number he gave police and Cheryl Johnson turned out to be fictitious.[6]
>Two days later, on May 24, the nude body of 27-year-old Nathaniel Cater, who had been missing for four days and was last seen with Williams, was discovered in the river. The medical examiner ruled he had died of probable asphyxia but never specifically said he had been strangled. Police thought that Williams had killed Cater and that his body was the source of the sound they heard as his car crossed the bridge.[7]
>Williams failed three polygraph tests. Hairs and fibers retrieved from the body of another victim, Jimmy Ray Payne, were found to be consistent with those from his home, car, and dog. Co-workers told police they had seen Williams with scratches on his face and arms around the time of the murders which, investigators surmised, could have been inflicted by victims during struggles.[7] Williams held a press conference outside his home to proclaim his innocence, volunteering that he had failed the polygraph tests, which would have been inadmissible in court.[8]
>Williams was questioned again by police for 12 hours on June 3 and 4 at FBI headquarters and released without arrest or charge, but remained under surveillance.[9]

>Arrest and trial
>Williams was arrested on June 21, 1981, for the murders of Cater and Payne.[10] His trial began on January 6, 1982, in Fulton County. During the two-month trial, prosecutors matched to a number of victims 19 sources of fibers from Williams's home and car: his bedspread, bathroom, gloves, clothes, carpets, dog, and an unusual trilobal carpet fiber. Other evidence included witness testimony that placed Williams with several victims while they were alive, and inconsistencies in his accounts of his whereabouts.[11] Williams took the stand in his own defense but alienated the jury by becoming angry and combative.[11] After 12 hours of deliberation, the jury found him guilty on February 27 of the murders of Cater and Payne. He was sentenced to life imprisonment.[12] After Williams became a suspect, the killings stopped.[2]
>In the late 1990s, Williams filed a habeas corpus petition and requested a retrial. Butts County Superior Court judge Hal Craig denied his appeal. Georgia Attorney General Thurbert Baker said that "although this does not end the appeal process, I am pleased with the results in the habeas case" and that his office will "continue to do everything possible to uphold the conviction."[13] In early 2004, Williams sought a retrial again, with his attorneys arguing that law enforcement officials covered up evidence of involvement by the Ku Klux Klan, and that carpet fibers purportedly linking him to the crimes would not stand up to scientific scrutiny.[14] A federal judge rejected the request for retrial on October 17, 2006.

It's a lot of fun, if you can get into the mindset. It's a weird, creepy, kind of low-budget pseudo-stage/indie production sci fi spoof, kind of an anti-Star Trek about a bunch of horrible people doing exactly the wrong things you'd expect from another show about a ragtag bunch of space misfits. It's hard to really communicate but you have to kind of put yourself in the era it came out, for its time, it was relatively mindblowing the kind of depravity they got away with on the show. Now it looks quaint and tame compared to the kind of shit we're always one click away from on the internet. But back in the day having a hot woman shower under an alien phallus on a world-destroying insect spaceship while a fat crazy cannibal carnival freak runs around exchanging quips with a sociopathic robot head stimulated all the right nodes of weirdness.

And as for Stan,

Stanley Tweedle was a rebel fighter who was abducted and repeatedly raped by "Feppo & Zepp" a pair of gay degenerate mercenaries. There's actually an entire song sung at one point to mock him for his repeated buttrapes, one of the few times I genuinely felt bad for Stan. He ends up sold to His Divine Shadow who uses data hidden in one of his teeth to track down the location of a bunch of rebel planets, Stan is blamed for their destruction and called "the arch-traitor" even though his real crime was just not killing himself before they could yank his tooth out. He was kept alive in case he could provide future information, but hated his life and role as a lowly security guard working for His Divine Shadow so he was repeatedly demoted until the point we meet him at the start of the series, where he's Class 4, already the absolute lowest rung of society. He becomes a fugitive after a bureaucratic error results in his punishment being he has to donate three organs to the protein bank, which he's described as "Typically they take your spares. Kidney, eye and testicle. But we're in a shortage so they'll probably take more."

He accidentally ends up carrying the key to the Lexx, the living ship the show is named for. As long as he has the key the ship will only obey his commands. So he's a useless, cowardly schlubb in control of a living ship that blows up planets and is roughly as intelligent as a dog.
